SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Moderate aplastic anemia (MAA) in children is a rare, idiopathic condition of bone marrow insufficiency that can resolve spontaneously, persist for months or years, or progress to severe aplastic anemia (SAA)
We evaluated the rate of progression to SAA
METHODS: We reviewed the records of 136 children referred for evaluation of bone marrow failure from 1978 to 2002 at St

MAA was defined by a hypocellular bone marrow (<50%) and 2 or 3 cytopenias (absolute neutrophil count <1,500/mm(3), absolute reticulocyte count <40,000/mm(3), platelet count <100,000/mm(3)) lasting at least 6 weeks
RESULTS: Twenty-four patients met the criteria for MAA
At a median follow-up of 66 months (range, 10-293), 16 patients (67%) progressed to SAA, 5 (21%) had persistent MAA, and 3 (12%) had complete resolution of MAA
No risk factors for progression could be identified
CONCLUSIONS: When childhood MAA is treated with supportive care alone, 2/3 of patients progress to SAA
